awd_titl_txt: Petascale quantum simulations of nano systems and biomolecules
awd_abstract_narration:
This award to North Carolina State University facilitates scientific research using the large, new, computational resource named Blue Waters being deployed at the University of Illinois in Urbana Champaign.  It provides travel funds to support technical coordination between the principal investigators at both North Carolina State University and University of Tennessee Knoxville, the Blue Waters project team and the vendor technical team.

This award aims to apply highly optimized quantum simulation codes to Blue Waters and to use them in four projects of high research interest.  In nano electronics, finding the optimal configurations of graphene-based transistors and obtaining its performance limits will help define future directions and goals of graphene-based electronics, which is by far the most active area of nano electronics at present.  In the nanotubes area, determining the most suitable catalysts for the growth of semiconducting tubes could greatly increase the availability of such tubes for sensor and electronics applications.  The much increased grasp of nanotube growth would also result in novel designs of nanotube-containing devices based on seeded growth in situ.  In the biosensor area, understanding the principles of operations is critical for further progress, which may result in extremely sensitive detection of DNA damage, important for early detection of cancer.  In Alzheimer disease, evaluation of the role of copper as a potential accelerating agent in the onset of the disease is clearly important, given its implications for disease prevention and potential strategies for drug development. 

In addition to the specific scientific projects described above, access to the project's open-source quantum simulation tools optimized for Blue Waters may benefit other projects and researchers.  These tools are broadly applicable to many projects in materials science, nano electronics, chemistry and molecular biology.  Components of these tools will likely be incorporated into tools developed by others, or form parts of specialized application suites.  At the two local institutions, this project will have educational impact by involving undergraduate and graduate students, as well as postdoctoral fellows, in leading-edge computational research.  Effort will be made to ensure participation of members of underrepresented groups.

por.por_cntn:
This project focuses on high-performance calculations for materials and devices of high current interest and on development of petascale methods for such simulations. We have carried out several investigations:

(i) Understanding key aspects of nitrogen cycle

The nitrogen cycle is a process in which nitrogen is converted between biological and non-biological forms. Nitri?cation converts atmospheric nitrogen into biological forms, while denitri?cation releases it back into the atmosphere as N2. Historically, denitri?cation balanced nitrogen ?xation, but human activity has altered this balance since the discovery of the Haber-Bosch process, which converts atmospheric nitrogen into ammonia for the production of fertilizers. The excess nitrogen causes many environmental problems, especially in aquatic ecosystems, such as eutrophication and harmful algal blooms. Natural denitri?cation is catalyzed by complex metalloenzymes with different transition metal cofactors. Our research determined the various steps in enzymatic conversion of nitrite into nitric oxide catalyzed by copper-containing nitride reductase (CuNiR). We show that change in the oxidation state of copper plays a central role in the reaction and map out the entire catalytic process, which involves coordinated electron and proton transfers, as well as significant structural rearrangements and conformational changes. Our results are in good agreement with the available experimental data.

(ii) Investigation of electron conduction in DNA and of their potential as “molecular wires”

The electrical conductivity of DNA molecules is of fundamental interest in life sciences and for potential use in nanoelectronics. The existence and the mechanism of DNA conductivity have been controversial by themselves, with a number of high-profile publications arriving at contradictory conclusions. Our work provides several new insights into this subject: (i) we show that coherent transport occurs over much longer distances than commonly assumed, (ii) we find that that instantaneous conformation of DNA is of critical importance, as it causes the current to change over many orders of magnitude, and (iii) we determine how DNA environment (solvent and ions) affect the charge transfer. A simple criterion for predicting DNA conductivity from its instantaneous geometrical arrangement is identified and validated by very large-scale supercomputer calculations. In addition to providing a simple means for understanding a perplexing variety of experimental observations and theoretical results, this criterion could be very useful to experimentalists attempting to design DNA-based circuits or sensors.

(iii) We investigated polymer-based capacitive energy storage materials with high dielectric constant, low dielectric loss, and high thermal stability. Such materials are needed for electronic, photovoltaic and automotive applications, where they could dramatically improve energy storage capacity and efficiency. Our results uncover a novel way to create high energy density polymers with low loss and high operating temperature.

(iv) We researched the sensing mechanisms of nanotube-based devices for the detection of small molecules, such ammonia, nitrogen dioxide, glucose and ethylene. For ammonia and nitrogen oxide, we show that only chemisorption near nanotube-metal contacts results in detectable signals. For glucose and ethylene, functionalization of nanotubes is required, and we identify the mechanisms involved in their detection.

(v) We simulated real-time electrical monitoring of DNA replication that uses a “Klenow fragment” (KF) of polymerase I enzyme attached to the surface of a carbon nanotube (CNT) by measuring the current flowing through the nanotube during replication. The enzyme is normally in an “open” state, but moves to closed state when the enzyme is attaching a new base pair. We used sophisticated quantum calculations to calculate transmission coefficients and currents for different enzymatic states. Our calculations show that the transmission spectrum and the current change significantly when the enzyme moves from the open to the closed state. While the original CNT-KF setup did not find significant differences between dissimilar bases, our theoretical work shows that both nucleotide analogs and gate potential scanning help distinguish between different DNA bases. At present, nucleotide substitutions and gating allows for distinquishing G and T bases. However, further work is needed to identify A and C.

(vi) We released a comprehensive suite of quantum codes for calculating the properties of materials at http://sourceforge.net/projects/rmgdft/ . It has already been downloaded over 1,700 times. Binaries for Linux, Windows and MacIntosh workstations are also being distributed. In addition to the source code and binaries, an extensive documentation and several examples are provided. Further users’ support is via forums and wiki. We are particularly emphasizing NSF-supported Centers, and are releasing versions adapted for the major NSF resource providers as community codes. A version for Blue Waters has already been released at http://bluewaters.ncsa.illinois.edu/rmg and a beta version for Stampede already exists. Our codes reached 1.14 petaflops on 3,872 Blue Waters Cray XK7 nodes.
